ai-mn49:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn49:2.1_0: “Mendicants, at one time I was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.
ai-mn49:2.2_0: Now at that time Baka the Brahmā had the following harmful misconception:
ai-mn49:2.3_0: ‘This is permanent, this is everlasting, this is eternal, this is whole, this is imperishable. For this is where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn. And there’s no other escape beyond this.’
ai-mn49:3.1_0: Then I knew what Baka the Brahmā was thinking.
ai-mn49:3.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-mn49:3.2_1: in that same way, when the Buddha had vanished, he appeared in that Brahmā realm.

ai-mn49:4.1_0: When he had spoken, I said to him,
ai-mn49:4.2_0: ‘Alas, Baka the Brahmā is lost in ignorance! Alas, Baka the Brahmā is lost in ignorance!
ai-mn49:4.3_0: Because what is actually impermanent, not lasting, transient, incomplete, and perishable, he says is permanent, everlasting, eternal, complete, and imperishable.

ai-mn49:4.6_0: And although there is another escape beyond this, he says that there’s no other escape beyond this.
ai-mn49:5.1_0: Then Māra the Wicked, without member of his retinue, pulling me out of that member and said to me,
ai-mn49:5.2_0: ‘Mendicant, mendicant! Don’t attack this one! Don’t attack this one! For this is Brahmā, the Great Brahmā, the Undefeated, the Champion, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, the Lord God, the Maker, the Author, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
ai-mn49:5.3_0: There have been ascetics and brahmins before you, mendicant, who criticized and loathed earth, water, air, fire, creatures, gods, the Creator, and Brahmā.
ai-mn49:5.4_0: When their bodies broke up and their breath was cut off they were reborn in a lower realm.
ai-mn49:5.5_0: There have been ascetics and brahmins before you, mendicant, who praised and approved earth, water, air, fire, creatures, gods, the Creator, and Brahmā.
ai-mn49:5.6_0: When their bodies broke up and their breath was cut off they were reborn in a higher realm.
ai-mn49:5.7_0: So, mendicant, I tell you this:
ai-mn49:5.8_0: please, good sir, do exactly what Brahmā says. Don’t go beyond the word of Brahmā.
ai-mn49:5.9_0: If you do, then the consequence for you will be like that of a person who, when Lady Luck approaches, wards her off with a staff, or someone who shoves away the ground as they fall down the chasm into hell.
ai-mn49:5.10_0: please, good sir, do exactly what Brahmā says. Don’t go beyond the word of Brahmā.

ai-mn49:5.12_0: And that is how Māra the Wicked presented the assembly of Brahmā to me as an example.

ai-mn49:7.2_0: ‘But, good sir, what I say is permanent, everlasting, eternal, complete, and imperishable is in fact permanent, everlasting, eternal, complete, and imperishable. And where I say there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn there is in fact
ai-mn49:7.3_0: no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn.
ai-mn49:7.4_0: And when I say there’s no other escape beyond this there is in fact no other escape beyond this.

ai-mn49:26.4_0: ‘I will vanish from the ascetic Gotama! I will vanish from the ascetic Gotama!’ But he was unable to vanish from me.

ai-mn49:31.1_0: And so, because of the silencing of Māra, and because of the invitation of Brahmā, the name of this discussion is “On the Invitation of Brahmā”.
